utterances: Aha, yeah.
And then, because I'm at 76-and-a-half now, I had the name Monroe before Marilyn Monroe.
But, a lot of people - the name Monroe immediately gets them in the head, oh, Marilyn Monroe, that sexy babe.
Aha.
Wonderful actress.
So, this is…
So, I mean, I'd like had a double barrel - and just this morning, my mother said - you know, we're talking about things and she said my grandmother was the one who suggested the name Monroe.
On the basis of what?
Well, she just liked the name.
But it hadn't been put in the hopper, you know, a possibility.
And the terrible irony is that my grandmother, who was a teacher, denied my mother the right to go to college even though she was an outstanding student.
So, I have this mixed sense of my grandmother.
You understand?
Yeah, I do.
I got…
Now, listen, I wish you the best of everything.
You do a wonderful job, and I think the way your group works to get angles on things is wonderful.
I mean, you're doing outstanding radio, let me say it to you.
I hope the people at WBAI, well, I hope they hear about this, but I hope they don't, you know, give me a needling that wasn't listening to…
To them.
…the programs on BAI.
Well, I think they'll forgive just this once.
Okay.
Well, carry on.
Monroe, thanks very much for the call.
Right.
Right.
Here's another e-mail.
This one from Karin(ph) in Tulsa, Oklahoma.
Naming your daughter after a city or a state can lead to problems for her later in life.

My - my step-grandmother had the first name Arizona, a beautiful name, in my opinion, but when she married my grandfather whose last name was Killings, she turned into a headline: Arizona Killings(ph).
Thanks very much for that.
If you'd like to join us, 800-989-8255.
E-mail talk@npr.org.
There's another side to naming as well.
Parents often struggle with what to name their kids.
It's that delicate balance between trying to come up with something original and making sure the name won't just cause more problems for their kids later on.
Joining us now is Michelle Botus.
She's the mother of four children and a job developer at a career development program in Boston, Massachusetts.
She's with us on the phone from her home there.
Nice to talk with you.
Hello.
Good afternoon.
How are you?
I'm well.
And what are your children's names?
My children's names are Asia Lkaye(ph), Alaysia Shannelle(ph), Khalima Michelle(ph) and Denzil Elijah(ph).
And those are beautiful names.
Thank you.
But why did you pick them specifically?
Okay.
While Asia was - she's the oldest, and when she was born, she had the most beautiful eyes that were slanted, oval-shaped eyes.
And the first thing that came to my mind was Southeast Asia.
So hence I named her Asia.
And my middle name was Kaye and I was trying to creative, so I put a - add L to the, well, the L to the Lkaye, to the a Kaye.
I see.
When Alicia was born, we wanted - you know, I wanted to continue with that geographical theme, but I also wanted to name, give her a name that began with an A and ended with an A because of Asia.
So…
Aha.
So there would be a match.
Yeah.
So while we did, we - you know, looked on the map and we thought Malaysia was beautiful and we took off the M.
Aha.
So her name is spelled - it's just like Malaysia without the M.
And Denzel?
Denzel Washington?
Well, no. That's my father's name.
Huh.
Dad's name is Denzil Botus.
He's Denzel - he was the first Denzil that I knew.
And, you know, I wanted to name my son after my dad, so I named him Denzil.
It's spelled differently then than Denzil Washington.
And the funny thing is my son had no idea who Denzil Washington was until at his after-school program, they would join this project, and he would get upset when people called him Denzil Washington.
He's like, I'm not Denzil Washington.
And they encouraged him to do some research and he did.
He found out who Denzil Washington was.
And when they presented this performance, my son played Denzil Washington so now he understands it.
But that's how he (unintelligible), and has been developed that he does not identify with any one with anyone, you know, but himself is being Denzil.
My son.

And somebody who's been in - works in broadly human resources, I know you are aware of studies that suggest that some kids with indefinably African-American names do not get as many job interviews as - if they we're named Kimberly or even Muffin.
Well, absolutely.
Some of us - some of the research that I read of show that for applicants with black names, they have - they get about 2 percent callbacks.
Whereas with, you know, normal European names - and excuse me for use in the word normal…
Yeah.
Okay.
…they get about 5 percent callback.
But, you know, I - you know, I'm one of those that to feel that it doesn't, you know, there's more to it than the name, you know?
I think about how for generations as immigrants came into this country, we had people that would choose - that we're changing their names.
We had Italians that we're changing their names, you know.
So, you know, it's been accustomed, it's been something that we've been doing for years.

However, I think today, we are becoming a more - as we become a more culturally diverse society and a lot more folks are sensitive to the diversity of, you know, the people that did live in this country.
And the other pieces that most - I think a lot of hiring managers and a lot of HR people are of that generation.
Ah, so this is going to improve with time.
This - absolutely.
Michelle Botus, we thank you for your optimism.
And Michelle is a beautiful name, too.
But this is a tiny little village in Ireland, who is eating all this stuff?
But people are.
And I think television has made this change possible.
People watch food shows, and they get ideas and they want to go out and try them.
Yours is a school play.
Are we seeing now, do you think, a trend...
Well, thank you.
Let me just add one more thing.

For my children, I think not only, you know, it's important for them to have a unique name, but developing their social skills, the interpersonal communication skills and making sure that they get a good ads education including, you know, higher education, all these will factor in.
And I'm totally confident in my children's career success and they are, you know, be a success as individuals in general.
